Dateline 2-15-2017 In a stinging defeat after months of negotiations, senators on Thursday failed to advance a bipartisan proposal to resolve the future of millions of young undocumented immigrants, leaving talks seemingly back at square one. A much-anticipated bipartisan deal that would have paired a pathway to citizenship for nearly 2 million undocumented immigrants who came to the US as children with $25 billion in border security and some other measures failed to get the 60 votes necessary to advance legislation after furious White House opposition.
The vote was 54-45.
A competing White House-backed plan that would have also substantially increased federal deportation powers, heavily cut family-based legal migration and ended the diversity visa also failed, 39-60.  -- https://www.cnn.com/2018/02/15/politics/trump-immigration-veto/index.html

McConnell seemed keen (interested, at the very least) to pursue legislation surrounding immigration, the border, and the DACA program. The question is whether Congressional Republicans would be able to consolidate around a set plan well enough to see it through (see: Obamacare repeal failure) or be able to round up enough votes from the other side of the aisle. The biggest issue is that it would be difficult to cater to both parties given how they would likely need to pair it with some form of toughened border security or restrictions to the eligible participants of the program to appease conservatives (which would likely only drive away Democrats) or provide softened enforcement in the form of a largely unrestricted DACA program which would deter already uneasy conservatives. There certainly seems to be a desire to get something done, but it largely depends on a widespread base of support in Congress, which is never a given. As for the President, he hasn't appeared to give a strong stance either way, so my best guess would sign the bill if it did pass.

Much less optimistic as the GOP delves into tax reform. That will consume most of the legislative calendar in the coming months, especially since it will be hard for them to pass that within the next 30 legislative days (while also passing an FY18 budget or CR, and a bipartisan budget deal to raise sequester caps). And as @JMR2017 points out, ACA repeal might be back on the docket for the spring (assuming tax reform is done one way or another by then). I look at how the GOP is approaching the CSR issue to shed light on how DACA will likely go. While there is some bipartisan support to solve the issue, the GOP and the WH seem determined to forge ahead alone and shun any pretense of reaching across the aisle beyond the individual level. With the GOP civil war in full swing as Bannon and McConnell trade shots, it is likely any GOP Reps. and Sens. up for reelection would have to pivot further right to fend off primary challengers. And as @Censusguyz points out, April will be primary season. The bottom line is governing is a hard, slow process, and its even harder and slower when done purely along partisan lines (I remember some clamoring about that over the past 7 years, but that was so long ago). With such a thin majority in the Senate and the strategy of using reconciliation to achieve legislative victories, the GOP has ensured any successes it has will be hard-earned and slow-arriving. To achieve anything beyond an EO or a DOJ policy by April (most likely just extending Congress's deadline), given the other significant legislative items and the need to work across the aisle, would be rather impressive.

Trump doesn't want this to pass Congress, as it allows him and the more populist, less compromising factions of the GOP to better position themselves for the 2018 primaries. Trump will demand that any DACA legislation comes with the Democrats conceding funds and authority to build the wall, which is essentially a non-starter for them. So, this is set up to fail. Additionally, Congress will have to balance this with tax reform, funding the government past December, figuring out what to do about the ACA exchanges, plus normal legislative work. DACA is not a high priority for the GOP, and Trump already indicated he would take some form of action if Congress failed to pass any legislation. Of course, the GOP continues to surprise, pursuing health care reform repeatedly despite burning up precious legislative time that could have been used for tax reform. So it always possible the GOP bows to Trump's whims and sidelines tax reform to pass some form of immigration legislation.
